qas.question: What made the oil crisis worse in the US?
Why are newly discovered oil sold at a higher price?

answers.text: The system limited the price of "old oil"

qas.question: Why was old oil withdrawn from the market?

answers.text: The system limited the price of "old oil"

qas.question: How was scarcity managed in many countries?
Why was old oil sold at a higher price?
What happened when new oil was withdrawn from the market?
What was rationing intended to promote in the market?
What action was taken to address price controls?

plausible_answers.text: Motorists faced long lines at gas stations

qas.question: How did old oil affect motorists in many countries?

context: <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4><a2_0><a2_1>Price controls<a2_1/><a2_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> exacerbated the crisis in the US. <a1_4><a2_4>The system limited the price of "old oil"<a2_4/><a1_4/> (that which had already been discovered) while allowing newly discovered oil to be sold at a higher price <a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><b4_0>to <a1_0>encourage investment<b4_0/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. Predictably, old oil was withdrawn from the market, creating <b5_0>greater scarcity<b5_0/>. The rule also <a2_3>discouraged development of alternative energies<a2_3/>. The rule had been intended to <a2_2>promote <b6_0>oil exploration<b6_0/><a2_2/>. Scarcity was addressed by <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><a3_4><b7_0>rationing<b7_0/><a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> (as in many countries). <b8_0>Motorists faced long lines at gas stations<b8_0/> beginning in summer 1972 and increasing by summer 1973.
